title-group.article-title: The association of mild cognitive impairment with outpatient visits for hypertension

aff.named-content: Department of Neurology and Stroke Program
Institute for Healthcare Policy and Innovation

aff.institution: The Dartmouth Institute for Health Policy and Clinical Practice.

author-notes.corresp: *CorrespondenceMellanie V. Springer, Department of Neurology and Stroke Program, 1500 East Medical Center drive, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan, 48109, USA. Email: mvsprin@med.umich.edu

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Hypertension management is critically important to reduce the risk of conversion of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) to dementia. The degree to which older adults with hypertension and MCI engage in outpatient ambulatory care for hypertension management is unclear.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: Among older adults with hypertension in the Rush Alzheimer's Disease Center (RADC) cohorts (2011 to 2019), we used repeated measures negative binomial regression to evaluate the association between cognitive status (MCI vs no cognitive impairment [NCI]) and number of annual outpatient clinic visits for hypertension evaluation and management (E&M) (primary outcome).

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: MCI (n = 1013 person‐years) was associated with 8% fewer outpatient visits for hypertension versus older adults with NCI (n = 4373 person‐years) (relative incidence ratio [RIR] 0.92, p < 0.01).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: Despite the known adverse cognitive effects of hypertension, older adults with MCI may be less likely to engage in outpatient hypertension management.

list-item.p: Fewer outpatient hypertension visits among adults with MCI versus NCI.
Fewer primary care hypertension visits among adults with MCI versus without MCI.
Need for interventions to engage adults with hypertension and MCI in outpatient care.

institution-wrap.institution: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

p.mixed-citation: SpringerMV, ChenY, BenloucifS, et al. The association of mild cognitive impairment with outpatient visits for hypertension. Alzheimer's Dement. 2025;21:e70743. 10.1002/alz.7074341014052

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Mild cognitive impairment (MCI), impairment in cognitive function with retained ability to carry out usual activities of daily living, 1 affects approximately 20% of adults 60 years of age and older in the United States. 2 , 3 Given the rapid rise in the population of older adults in the United States, the number of older adults with MCI is expected to similarly increase. 4 Few studies have investigated health care utilization among older adults with MCI. One study showed that, in general, older adults with MCI have higher medical expenditures than older adults without cognitive impairment, largely due to higher use of inpatient services. 5 The converse may be true for use of outpatient services, with one study showing lower use of outpatient services (e.g., outpatient surgeries and procedures) among older adults with MCI compared to older adults without cognitive impairment. 6 In that study, there was a trend for older adults with MCI to have fewer outpatient clinic visits than those without cognitive impairment. 6

Hypertension is a risk factor for the conversion of MCI to dementia. 7 Slowing the progression of MCI to dementia could lower the future burden of dementia. The elimination of hypertension during midlife would reduce cases of dementia by 2% worldwide. 8 Outpatient clinic visits for hypertension with a primary care provider are essential to achieving blood pressure control. 9 We found that the annual number of outpatient primary care visits did not differ between older community‐dwelling adults with MCI and adults without cognitive impairment. 10 Little is known about outpatient care utilization among older adults with MCI and hypertension, a population for whom hypertension management is critically important to reduce the risk of progression to dementia. Limiting the population of older adults to those with hypertension and examining outpatient visits for hypertension, we sought to investigate how older adults with MCI compared to those without cognitive impairment in outpatient visits for hypertension management.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: Data from participants enrolled in Rush Alzheimer's Disease Center (RADC) cohort studies of aging were linked to Medicare claims records for the years 2011 to 2019, which were obtained through a data use agreement with the National Institute on Aging (NIA). Although linked Medicare claims data are available through 2022, we excluded years after 2019 due to the COVID pandemic. In‐person ambulatory care visits may have decreased by as much as 37% among insured patients during the peak of the COVID pandemic. 11 Inclusion of data during the COVID pandemic would have affected our estimation of the mean annual number of visits, irrespective of participant cognitive status. We therefore excluded years after 2019. Informed consent was obtained from participants in each cohort study of aging and for Medicare linkage. All cohort studies of aging were approved by the Rush University Medical Center Institutional Review Board.

sec.title: Cohort studies
sec.p: The RADC cohort studies of aging include the Rush Memory and Aging Project (MAP), Religious Orders Study (ROS), Minority Aging Research Study (MARS), and the African American Clinical Core (AA core). The MAP cohort enrolls participants residing in retirement communities and homes from the Chicago metropolitan area and Northeastern Illinois. Recruitment began in 1997. 12 The ROS cohort enrolls nuns, brothers, and priests from across the United States. Recruitment for the ROS cohort began in 1994. 12 The MARS cohort and AA core both enroll African American adults from the Chicago metropolitan area. Recruitment from senior buildings, churches, social clubs, and other organizations began in 2004 for the MARS cohort and in 2008 for the AA core. 13 , 14 Only older adults without known dementia at baseline are eligible to participate in the cohort studies. Recruitment and follow‐up are ongoing for all cohort studies. Retention of participants is 85% to 90% across all cohorts.

sec.title: Cognitive evaluations
sec.p: A neuropsychological test battery consisting of 21 tests, of which 18 were common to all cohorts, assessing cognitive domains of episodic memory, working memory, semantic memory, perceptual speed, and visuospatial ability/perceptual orientation, was administered annually. The cognitive tests comprising each of the five cognitive domains are scored, and a level of impairment is assigned for each based on test performance. An expert neuropsychologist reviews the impairment ratings and incorporates clinical information to render a judgment regarding the presence of dementia. 15 , 16 MCI is diagnosed if participants are classified as having cognitive impairment by the neuropsychologist but do not meet the National Institute of Neurological and Communicative Disorders and Stroke and the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association (NINCDS/ADRDA) criteria for dementia as assessed by an expert clinician (geriatrician, neurologist, or geriatric nurse practitioner). 17 Participants without a diagnosis of MCI or dementia were classified as no cognitive impairment (NCI).

list-item.p: Systematic review: The authors used scientific databases (e.g., PubMed) to review the literature regarding health care utilization among older adults with MCI. There are few studies investigating MCI and health care utilization, and none related to hypertension.
Interpretation: Our findings fill a gap in the knowledge base regarding potential gaps in outpatient care for hypertension among older adults with MCI.

Future directions: Future studies that stem from our findings could include (1) evaluating whether outpatient care utilization among older adults with MCI and hypertension depends on primary care provider knowledge of a MCI diagnosis and (2) investigating reasons that older adults with hypertension and MCI have fewer outpatient visits than older adults without cognitive impairment.

sec.title: Outcome
sec.p: The primary outcome was the total number of outpatient visits for hypertension in the 12 months following each participant's cohort evaluation. Outpatient evaluation and management (E&M) ambulatory medical visits for hypertension were determined from the Medicare Fee‐For‐Service (FFS) carrier and outpatient claims (to capture federally qualified health center visits). The Current Procedural Terminology (CPT) codes used to define E&M visits included 99202‐99205, 99212‐99215, 99381‐99387, 99391‐99397, G0438, G0439, and G0402. Definitions of each of the CPT codes are included in Table S1. From these E&M visits we identified visits for hypertension by International Classification of Diseases‐9th Revision (ICD‐9) diagnosis codes for hypertension, including 401.0, 401.1, 401.9, 405.01, 405.09, 405.11, 405.19, 405.91, and 405.99, and ICD‐10 diagnosis codes for hypertension, including I10, I15.0, I15.1, I15.2, I15.8, I15.9, I16.0, I16.1, I16.9, and I1A.0. Secondary outcomes were the total number of outpatient E&M visits for hypertension in the 12 months following each participant's cohort evaluation by provider specialty, the total number of outpatient E&M visits that were not for hypertension in the 12 months following each participant's cohort evaluation, and the number of outpatient E&M visits following each participant's cohort evaluation regardless of the reason for the visit. We categorized E&M visits by provider specialty with the provider taxonomy code associated with the National Provider Identifiers (NPI) number of the provider. We categorized provider specialties into primary care and medical specialties. The provider specialty categorizations can be found in Table S2. We defined outpatient E&M visits that were not for hypertension as outpatient E&M visits that did not have an ICD‐9 or ICD‐10 code for hypertension.

sec.title: Participant characteristics
sec.p: Participants self‐reported age, sex (male vs female), race and ethnicity (non‐Hispanic Black, non‐Hispanic White, Hispanic ethnicity, or other race), and years of education at cohort baseline. Marital status (married, single, or unknown) was reported by participants at the cohort baseline and at annual follow‐up. We calculated the Elixhauser comorbidity count using Medicare claims data during the 12 months before the cohort evaluation, which is a sum of a participant's comorbid conditions. 18 The number of hospitalizations in the 12 months before each participant's cohort evaluation was also calculated.

sec.title: Analytic population
sec.p: Our analytic sample was selected from participants in the RADC cohort studies during the years 2011 through 2018. Participants were required to have a diagnosis of hypertension in the RADC cohort, assessed by self‐report or by review of antihypertensive medication bottles. Outcomes were observed for 12 months after the date of the cohort evaluation in each year of participation. Eligible participants were at least 66 years old so that medical comorbidities could be determined from Medicare claims data in the 12 months prior to each participant's cohort evaluation. Only RADC cohort participants who were continuously enrolled in Medicare FFS, Part A and Part B, for 12 months before and 12 months after their RADC cohort evaluation were included, or until death in the 12‐month observation period. We excluded all person‐years in which the cohort evaluation indicated the presence of dementia since we were only interested in MCI. We censored participants at admission to a long‐term nursing facility.

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: We used repeated measures with 12‐month follow‐up periods. For each 12‐month follow‐up period (i.e., cohort year), we updated each participant's cognitive status (MCI or NCI), as well as covariates. We used descriptive statistics to characterize demographic and clinical information of cohort participants averaged across all person‐years. Means and standard deviations (SDs) were used for normally distributed continuous variables. The median and interquartile range were used for skewed continuous variables. Categorical variables were described using the number and percentage in each category.

First, we examined the distribution of the number of visits over 12 months (e.g., mean, variance, the ratio of Poisson residual deviance over degrees of freedom). Because there was evidence of overdispersion (deviance/degrees of freedom = 4.34, which is >1), we used a negative binomial mixed‐effects model to evaluate the association between cognitive status (MCI vs NCI) and number of visits over each 12‐month follow‐up period. Separate negative binomial mixed‐effects models were performed for each outcome (total number of outpatient visits for hypertension, total number of outpatient visits for hypertension by provider specialty, total number of outpatient visits not for hypertension, and total number of outpatient visits regardless of the reason for the visit). Each model adjusted for age, sex, years of education, RADC cohort, and Elixhauser comorbidity count as fixed effects. Because some RADC cohorts recruit specific races/ethnicities, we did not add race/ethnicity to the adjusted models. Additionally, each model included participant‐specific random intercepts to account for the correlation in the repeated measures. Models estimated the adjusted relative incidence ratio (RIR) of outpatient visits among participants with MCI compared to participants with NCI. Models were also used to predict the adjusted marginal mean number of annual visits of MCI and NCI participants, considering equal‐weight average over categorical‐covariate levels and mean continuous covariates for the prediction. Statistical analyses were performed with SAS version 9.4 (SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC, USA).

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: Table 1 shows participant characteristics by cognitive status. The study included a total of 5386 person‐years of older adults with hypertension. Data were available for all person‐years included in the study. Of these, there were 1013 person‐years of MCI and 4373 person‐years of NCI. Older adults with hypertension and MCI had a mean ± SD age of 84.7 ± 7.0 years old. Older adults with hypertension and MCI were 76.8% female, had a mean ± SD of 16.2 ± 3.5 years of education, and were 25.8% non‐Hispanic Black adults, 70.2% non‐Hispanic White adults, and 4% Hispanic ethnicity and other racial groups. Older adults with hypertension and NCI had a mean ± SD age of 80.9 ± 7.3 years and a mean ± SD of 16.0 ± 3.5 years of education and were 80.1% female; 29.6% were non‐Hispanic Black adults, 67.3% were non‐Hispanic White adults, and 3.1% were Hispanic adults and other racial groups.

caption.p: Characteristics of participants by cognitive status in person‐years (2011 to 2018).

fn.p: Abbreviations: AA, African American Clinical Core; IQR, interquartile range; MAP, Rush Memory and Aging Project; MARS, Minority Aging Research Study; ROS, Religious Orders Study; SD, standard deviation.

sec.title: Number of outpatient visits adjusted for demographic and clinical variables
sec.p: Table 2 shows the adjusted number of outpatient visits and their association with cognitive status. Among older adults with hypertension, MCI was associated with fewer outpatient visits for hypertension than NCI (marginal adjusted predicted mean 1.8 [95% CI: 1.7 to 2.0] visits/year for adults with MCI versus 2.0 [95% CI: 1.9 to 2.1] visits/year for adults with NCI). Among older adults with hypertension, MCI was associated with 8% fewer outpatient visits for hypertension than NCI (RIR 0.92, p < 0.01).

caption.p: Predicted number of outpatient visits by cognitive status (MCI vs NCI) and relative incidence ratio.

tr.th: a Predicted mean number of visits (95% confidence interval)

tr.td: Outpatient visits for hypertension by provider type

fn.p: Note: Relative incidence ratio refers to the number of visits of those with mild cognitive impairment compared to those with no cognitive impairment (reference).
Abbreviations: MCI, mild cognitive impairment; NCI, no cognitive impairment.

Predicted marginal mean, adjusted for sex, age, education, Elixhauser comorbidity count, and cohort (Rush Memory and Aging Project, Religious Orders Study, Minority Aging Research Study, and African American Clinical Core), considering equal‐weight average over categorical‐covariate levels and mean continuous covariates for the prediction.

sec.p: Among older adults with hypertension, MCI was associated with fewer outpatient visits for hypertension with a primary care provider than NCI, but outpatient visits for hypertension with a medical specialist, while low for both, did not differ between adults with MCI and NCI. For outpatient visits with a primary care provider, MCI was associated with a marginal adjusted predicted mean of 1.5 (95% CI: 1.4 to 1.7) outpatient visits/year, while NCI was associated with a marginal adjusted predicted mean of 1.7 (95% CI: 1.6 to 1.8) outpatient visits/year. MCI was associated with 9% fewer visits/year with a primary care provider than NCI (RIR 0.91, p < 0.01).

Regardless of the reason for the visit, MCI was associated with fewer outpatient visits than NCI (marginal adjusted predicted mean 7.3 [95% CI: 6.9 to 7.7] visits/year for adults with MCI versus 7.9 [95% CI: 7.6 to 8.3] visits/year for adults with NCI).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: We found that among older adults with hypertension, MCI was associated with fewer outpatient visits for hypertension than NCI in total and with primary care providers. These findings are critically important because they show that older adults with hypertension and MCI, for whom hypertension control may prevent transition to dementia, may be receiving less outpatient hypertension management than similar people with NCI.

Although our study was not designed to identify reasonsolder adults with hypertension and MCI have fewer hypertension outpatient visits than those without cognitive impairment, both patient and provider factors may be contributing. Coordinating medical appointments and other aspects of hypertension self‐management may be activities that are challenging for older adults with MCI, possibly due to impairments in executive function and memory. Family support and more years of education have been associated with regular clinic attendance among older adults with MCI. 19 Family can assist with coordination of appointments, and more highly educated adults with MCI may be able to better compensate for their cognitive deficits than their less educated peers. Second, in our study, the primary care providers may not be aware of the MCI diagnosis because older adults were diagnosed with MCI at their research visit rather than in clinical care. In usual care, lack of physician awareness of MCI is common, with nearly three‐quarters of primary care providers across the US reporting difficulty differentiating between MCI and normal aging. 3 In real‐world settings, primary care providers assess fewer than half of their older adult patients for cognitive impairment. 3 Furthermore, primary care providers administer a cognitive screening test and refer patients who screen positive for cognitive impairment for a full neuropsychological test battery. 20 By contrast, study participants were administered a full neuropsychological test battery at each of their annual research visits. If primary care providers were aware of a MCI diagnosis, additional strategies might be employed to promote regular clinic visits for hypertension management among their patients with MCI. Future research is needed to determine whether physician awareness of MCI can mitigate the impact of MCI on hypertension management.

The strengths of our study include the evaluation of outpatient service utilization for hypertension in a large cohort of adults with rigorous clinician‐adjudicated MCI and NCI. Among limitations, ICD‐9 and 10 diagnosis codes were used to identify outpatient visits for hypertension, but it is unknown whether hypertension was actually managed during the outpatient clinic visit or the level of hypertension control. Future research is needed to determine whether lower outpatient visit frequency among older adults with MCI and hypertension is associated with poor blood pressure control or higher rates of cardiovascular events compared to patients with NCI. Second, participants in RADC are not selected to be nationally representative, which may limit generalizability, but the similar recruitment and evaluation of cognition lead to strong internal validity in the comparison between adults with MCI and NCI.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: Among older adults with hypertension, MCI was associated with fewer outpatient visits for hypertension than NCI. Future research should identify reasons for the association between cognitive status and outpatient visits for hypertension and strategies to engage adults with MCI in outpatient care for hypertension. Focus groups of adults with MCI and hypertension may reveal areas in which to intervene to increase outpatient care utilization. Interventions are critically needed to engage adults with MCI in outpatient care, given the known adverse cognitive outcomes associated with poor hypertension control.

sec.title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST STATEMENT

MVS received an honorarium and travel reimbursement for a lecture at Oregon Health & Science University. YC, SB, FG, AWC, MB, and JPWB have nothing to disclose. Author disclosures are available in the supporting information.

sec.title: CONSENT STATEMENT
sec.p: All participants provided consent for participation in each cohort study of aging and for Medicare linkage.
